They gave false info about natural and synthetic brushes. While an artist preference can be a factor, the choice of brush is primarily dependent on the medium you are planning to use. A general rule of thumb is to use a synthetic brush with synthetic mediums. And a natural brush with natural mediums. However, it is also important to understand that both natural and synthetic brushes use a wide range of materials for the bristles of the brush. Each produces different results. This is where preference comes into play. Once you gain a basic understanding of how different brushes behave with different mediums, then you can learn to use those brushes to produce different effects in your work. Weather you are an artist or a craftsman, take the time to learn about the different sizes, shapes and materials used is brushes. Learn how each behaves with the mediums you enjoy using. Once you do, you will be one step closer to mastering your art or craft. And don't stop there, there are many more tools than just brushes. You will be amazed by what you can accomplish if you are willing to explore and learn.

My aunt was an homemade artist in soviet union. The thing about USSR is that one can buy one thing, but there was a significant absence of corresponding quality product to go along with it. For example: There was quality Leningrad honey watercolors, BUT there was no quality brushes, so my aunt made a selection of home made brushes from her cat hair. Still hast hem to this day. The brushes are soft and look professionally made, cause her husband worked in metal factory and made her professional metal casings to hold the hair.
